Present :

Minute 2.) good contact being obtained in many cases. These attacks included the sinking of the " U. 27 " by Fortune 85 miles west of Butt of Lewis. The Captain and full crew had been captured.
The skipper of a trawler had reported that, when passing two destroyers near Flamborough Head, he had passed over and struck what he believed to be a submerged submarine. An eruption of black oil had been observed.
A Polish submarine had escaped out of the Baltic, and had asked for a rendez-vous in the North Sea.
The War Cabinet :
(1) Took note of the above statements.
(2) Agreed that the Prime Minister should include in his
statement to the House of Commons that afternoon an account of our successes against German submarines, and should emphasise that, in contrast with the last war, we were now conducting a vigorous anti-U-boat campaign, which would increase in intensity as we developed our resources.

(39) 20th were still holding out in the Pripet Marshes, and also in the area Conclusions, between Warsaw and Radom, where there were probably about Minute 4.) 100,000 Polish troops. The German attack on Warsaw was coming from the North and not from the West, in which direction there seemed to be few German troops. There was no news of any movement of German Divisions to the West from Poland.
The position as regards the oil wells in Galicia was that the Western group of wells was in the hands of the Germans, and the Eastern group in the hands of the Russians. A dispute appeared to be going on between the Russians and the Germans as to the possession of the middle group of wells near Lemberg. So far as was known, all, or practically all, the refineries had been destroyed, but not the wells themselves.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement.

Provision of 5 in connection with the preceding item, discussion took place
Heavy Artillery as to the provision of heavy artillery for the British Field Force, for the Army. Reference was made to the large war stocks of heavy howitzers, and it was suggested that immediate steps should be taken to modernise these stocks so as to increase their range, on the same lines as the French had adopted. If heavy guns were required for counter-battery work, the Admiralty could make some available.
The War Cabinet
(1) invited the War Office and Ministry of Supply to consider
what immediate steps could be taken for the modernisation of existing stocks of heavy artillery;
(2) took note that the Admiralty could, if necessary, provide
a certain quantity of long-range guns and ammunition for the use of the Army.
Land Forces.
Second Report of Committee. (Previous Reference : W.M. (39) 9th Conclusions, Minute 6.)
6. The Prime Minister said that, in view of the fact that the Second Report of the Land Forces Committee (W.P. (39) 37) had only just been circulated, he proposed that the discussion should be of a preliminary character only, a decision being deferred until Friday, the 22nd September, 1939, when, in addition, those members of the War Cabinet who were not present, would have returned.
At the conclusion of the discussion, a record of which is being circulated separately, the War Cabinet agreed :
(a) to defer a decision on the questions raised in the Second
Report by the Land Forces Committee (W.P. (39) 37) until the meeting of the War Cabinet to be held on Friday, the 22nd September, 1939;
(b) that, before the meeting of the War Cabinet referred to
in (a) above, the Chancellor of the Exchequer should circulate a paper (i) comparing our present monthly expenditure with that at the end of the last war (exclusive of expenditure then financed from American loans); (ii) discussing the dollar expenditure involved in the proposals of the Land Forces Committee in relation to our total dollar resources;
(c) to take note that the Prime Minister contemplated making
a statement regarding the scale on which we proposed to carry on the war on the lines of recommendation (a) as summarised in paragraph 4 of the Second Report of the Land Forces Committee;
(d) that the Secretary of State for Air, in consultation with
the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, should continue to make provisional plans for the despatch at a very early date of an Air Mission to Canada for the purpose of making arrangements with the Canadian Government for the training of personnel and for the expansion of the aircraft-production industry in that Dominion.

In the course of the subsequent discussion the following points emerged :
(i) considerable apprehensions were still entertained by the
Chiefs of Staff Committee in regard to the activities of Marshal Weygand in the Balkans;
(ii) a further telegram had been sent the previous evening, the
19th September, 1939, to His Majesty's Ambassador, Paris, instructing him to urge upon the French Government the need for the utmost caution in regard to Marshal Weygand's activities; (iii) the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs was considering instructing His Majesty's Ambassador, Rome, to warn Count Ciano that in certain eventualities it might be necessary for us to take some action in the Balkans, but that the interests of Italy would not be prejudiced by SEP such action.

9. The Chief of the Air Staff suggested that the comments of the French Military Representatives on the Supreme War Council should be invited on the Appreciation by the Chiefs of Staff on the possible future course of the war (W.P. (39) 33).
The opportunity could be used to obtain the views of the French General Staff on Allied Strategy in the Balkans, with particular reference to Marshal Weygand's activities. (See Minute 8.)
The War Cabinet agreed :
That a copy of the Appreciation by the Chiefs of Staff on the possible future course of the war (W.P. (39) 33) should be handed to the French Military Representatives on the Supreme War Council, and their comments invited.
Interview with 10. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that at
Dr. Benes. a meeting the previous day Dr. Benes had stated that he was very sanguine regarding the present anti-German efforts of the Czechs in Czecho-Slovakia. He (the Secretary of State) had exhorted Dr. Benes to encourage his followers to maintain a campaign of sabotage and to avoid a rising in open rebellion. In the course of the conversation, Dr. Benes had raised the following questions :
(i) Was the restoration of Czecho-Slovakia one of the British
war aims ?
(ii) Would it be possible for His Majesty's Government to
accord a juridical basis to the Czech Government of which Dr. Benes was the head ? (iii) Would it be possible to arrange in this country for the enrolment of Czech units?
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs summarised his views in regard to these questions as follows :
(a) He had informed Dr. Benes, as regards his first question,
that His Majesty's Government had decided, for the present at least, to take no decision as regards war aims, except the securing, by every possible means, of the defeat of Germany.
(b) Dr. Benes's second question was under consideration; his
(the Secretary of State's) present feeling was that this request should be granted. The Czech Legation in London was still recognised.
(c) The Foreign Office were in communication with the War
Office in regard to Dr. Benes's third point.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs drew attention to a telegram which had been received from His Majesty's Minister in Bucharest, from which it appeared that the Roumanian Government were raising great difficulties about allowing the Polish Government to leave Roumanian soil. He had, accordingly, addressed a telegram, the previous evening (19th September, 1939), to Sir Reginald Hoare requesting him to take all possible action to assist the departure from Roumania of the Polish Government, and authorising him, if necessary, to make arrangements himself for the Polish Ministers to leave Roumania by air.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs stated that His Majesty's Ambassador, Washington, and his French colleague, had arranged to discuss that day with the State Department the question of the reply to be given to the Japanese suggestion for the withdrawal of garrisons and warships from China by belligerent countries. The situation would be clearer when a report had been received from Lord Lothian, but at present he (the Secretary of State) felt that we should not pursue further the question of withdrawing our garrisons either from Tientsin or from Shanghai. There was a possibility that the Japanese Government did not intend to press this suggestion.
The Secretary of State was very anxious to effect a settlement of the Tientsin question, and he hoped that it might be possible to do this by making an arrangement with the Japanese Government in regard to the disposal of the silver now held in the Concession. A decision by the War Cabinet on this difficult question would be needed in the course of the next few days.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

(a) agreed that the Air Ministry should inform the Polish
Mission in London that steps had been taken to divert the steamship Laselle, which had been on her way to Roumania with a consignment of aircraft and armaments for Poland :
(b) took note that arrangements had been made to suspend the
sailing from Liverpool of the Polish steamship Robur VIII, with a further consignment of armaments originally intended for Poland :
(c) invited the Air Ministry to discuss with the Foreign Office
any technical difficulties arising from the fact that the steamship Robur VIII was a Polish vessel.

Extension of 17. The Home Secretary and Minister for Home Security
Summer Time, asked authority from the War Cabinet to announce forthwith that
summer time, which would ordinarily have ended on 8th October,
would be extended to 18th November.
The matter had been considered in consultation with the French
Government, who were prepared to extend summer time to
18th November and were anxious to make their announcement that
day.
Inquiries which had been made showed that feeling in England and Wales was almost unanimous as to the necessity for an extension of summer time, but that opinion in Scotland was opposed to the change.
The War Cabinet approved the action proposed by the Home Secretary and Minister for Home Security.
Merchant Ship 18. The War Cabinet had before them a memorandum by the
Construction. President of the Board of Trade (W.P. (G.) (39) 15) on the question of the construction of merchant vessels on Government account.
The President of the Board of Trade stated that our existing plan, approved by the Committee of Imperial Defence, provided for the construction of about 1,100,000 tons in the first year of war, whether on private or Board of Trade account. At the outbreak of war there was on order a total of 730,000 tons and he had immediately given orders to increase this amount by 100,000 tons. He now asked for authority to place orders for another 200,000'tons and invited the War Cabinet to approve the principle of maintaining an annual output of not less than 1,100,000 tons.
The War Cabinet agreed :
(a) to approve the proposal of the President of the Board of
Trade that he should place orders for a further 200,000 tons of shipbuilding:
(b) to approve the principle of maintaining an annual output of
not less than 1,100,000 tons gross of shipping, whether on commercial or Board of Trade account, subject to the approval of the Treasury being obtained to the placing of further orders, on Board of Trade account, as and when necessary :
(c) to invite the Board of Trade to consult with the Admiralty
in regard to the strength of the bulkheads in new merchant vessels.

The War Cabinet gave a general approval in principle to the above proposals, subject:
(i) to the deletion of the word " substantial " in the first line
of proposal (a), further purchases of tobacco not being allowed except where the contractual arrangements made it impossible to stop the conclusion of the transactions :
(ii) to no action to restrict imports from Canada being taken
for 48 hours; during this interval the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs would be in consultation with the Canadian Government regarding the proposals which affected them:
(iii) to the caveat that the Minister of Food should not be
debarred from pursuing his present policy of buying food for this country in the most advantageous markets.
